Building scalable web experiences for Questrade

When Questrade needed to modernize its website, I led the push for a user-centered approach that improved engagement, boosted clarity, and increased conversions.

Key Results

25,573

new prospect in 6 months

+7M sessions

in 12 months

+1.2%

increase in attributed revenue

Revenue expressed as % for NDA reasons

Information architecture

Timeline

2023—2024

The problem

A web experience that was
showing its age

It's 2018. Schitt’s Creek is a breakout hit, Beyoncé was making history headlining Coachella, and Questrade.com got its last major update. The site was working, but by 2021, when I joined, cracks were starting to show.

  • Low information scent. We used internal jargon that made it hard for users to find what they needed.

  • Lack of engagement. Most pages had bounce rates over 80%, and ~60-70% of users dropped off immediately after the hero banner.

  • Outdated look-and-feel. Inconsistent elements and layouts across pages was hurting our credibility.

The challenge

Fixing these problems wasn’t just about aesthetics, the stakes were real.

Questrade’s website was falling behind. Users expected faster, simpler experiences, but our content, design, and IA weren’t keeping up. Competitors were gaining ground, and high bounce rates were hurting acquisition and brand perception.

We needed a plan.

Through cross-functional collaboration with product, engineering and content teams I outlined our major tasks:

1

Research and Analysis

Dig deep with content audits, competitive analysis and user research

2

Refreshed Information Architecture

Develop a clear IA that can scale with business needs and support the creation of additional content

3

SEO-optimized content strategy

Create a scalable strategy that would boost traffic and work for all our landing pages

4

New look-and-feel without starting over

Develop a phased visual refresh to unify the site and bring it up to modern standards

Research and Analysis

Understanding the Problem Space

I led my team's research, where we dove deep into our existing content and structure, talked to users and pulled insights.

  • Content audit. Understand page performance and identify improvement areas.

  • Tree Testing. Benchmark IA and validate navigation updates.

  • User interviews. Learn about user expectations and perceptions.

  • Competitive Analysis. Spot gaps and gather effective design patterns from competitors.

"I’m not sure what a Questwealth Portfolio is exactly or why I’d need one."
— Quote from one our interviewees

What our research was telling us

  • Branded terms confused most users.
  • Account type content was only found after several attempts.
  • Many struggled to find our trading apps, likely due to unclear labeling.
  • Mixing technical and domain content in the learning centre made discovery harder.
